How to Cut Cherry Tomatoes Fast | Bon Appétit




Skip to main contentOpen Navigation MenuMenuStory SavedTo revisit this article, visit My Profile, then View saved stories.Close AlertCloseStory SavedTo revisit this article, select My Account, then View saved storiesClose AlertCloseSign InSearchRecipesCookingCultureShoppingRestaurantsBA MarketVideosPodcastMerch ShopcookingI Will Not Apologize for the Dorky Way I Cut Cherry TomatoesLaugh all you want: I will beat you in a cherry tomato cutting contest.By Sarah JampelAugust 13, 2019FacebookTwitterEmailPhoto by Chelsie Craig, Food Styling by Olivia Mack McCoolFacebookTwitterEmailScrolling through Pinterest is a lot like shopping at a thrift store: For every 100 pieces of junk, you’ll find one treasure. So while a “hack” for cutting a whole bunch of cherry tomatoes between two quart container lids might seem gimmicky at first (and every time I do it in front of Carla Lalli Music or Chris Morocco, I blush a deep crimson), believe me when I tell you: This one works! This is the treasure! This is that pair of timeless vintage Levis. (Okay, simile stops now.)Here’s how to do it: Place the first quart container lid on your counter, right side up. Then pack on the cherry tomatoes in an even layer and cover with the second lid, upside down (the rims of the two containers will act as a barrier and keep your tomatoes in place). Use a knife—a really sharp chef knife or, my preference, a serrated knife—to slice parallel to the counter, thereby halving all of those tomatoes. Repeat the process until you have enough halved tomatoes to make this Ratatouille Pasta.Sure, you could slice the tomatoes one by one...but, excuse me, do I look like I’m made of time? There’s TV to watch! There’s news to avoid! Even though this trick has been making the internet rounds since the beginning of time, every time I execute it, I get looks of revelatory amazement. Or maybe people are just embarrassed for me? Using this 2003 “hack” that got buried under piles of content?Whatever the look on their faces means, I do know one thing: I’d totally beat them in a cherry tomato-cutting contest.Now it's pasta time:Ratatouille PastaIf we were to round up an all-star team of summer's greatest produce, it'd look a little something like ratatouille: Eggplant and zucchini.
